intro: Centaurea pentelica, commonly known as the Greek cornflower, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring blue to purple ray florets and yellow disk florets. Its leaves are lanceolate and covered with fine hairs, while its roots are fibrous and adapted to rocky soils. Centaurea pentelica is often found in dry grasslands and along coastal areas, where it thrives in sunny, well-drained conditions.
